segments.text: ...African agricultural research capabilities was National Academy of Sciences.
I spent about six weeks on that trip.
And then...
Prior to that actually.
That's when that was published.
And then I spent some time in Pakistan for the World Bank on this one.
Which is the same sort of deal in principle as that.
I see.
Livestock production and marketing in Pakistan.
I spent a month over there with two other fellows working on that project.
West Pakistan.
And you wrote Evaluation of Livestock Health Practices in Pakistan, I see.
So it's a combined effort here.
That's right.
I visited all their research labs, trying to help them with these projects.
And you took your knowledge to them.
Did they have some of the same problems?
Yes, they had problems with African horse sickness.
I also spent, while I was in the Army actually,
Before I left the Army, I spent a good many months in many countries of Africa and Asia on African horse sickness because it was a national threat to this country, you see.
And the Army sent me over there from the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology.
Well in Africa and in Turkey and Iran and Afghanistan and Pakistan and India, all those places on African horse sickness and wrote numerous papers about it that are listed there.
Now when you went to some of these governments, all of these governments that you went to in the 1960s were so-called West-oriented governments.
Did the State Department give you any, did they tell you or did any officials from the United States government tell you about what the Communists or what the Soviets were attempting to do?
No, I had security clearances, of course, during that time.
Sure, because of your dealings with the Army, your career with the Army.
The only time I had to be careful from a Russian point of view was in taking photographs in Iran and Turkey, at which time there was some
Russian participation in highway development in those countries and some things of that sort.
But I never went to any communist-dominated countries at that time.
Were you ever briefed by the CIA when you came back from these trips?
Yes.
Yeah, that was done.
They basically wanted to know about the food production?
interior of the nation?
Yeah, that's right.
They were concerned about- Just general intelligence?
General intelligence.
But I'd rather really not talk about that aspect of it much because I did have some relations with the CIA at that time.
Now, I was also wondering about something that you said.
And that is that drug manufacturing companies supplied money for this.
Yes, they did for- Which companies?
Well, I'd have to look it up to be sure now.
But what they did was simply that they had some drugs which they wanted to evaluate for their therapeutic effect against these diseases we were working on.
And this we did and reported back to them and were compensated for the work.
And so basically, did they give you about a third of the funding, or less?
No, it wasn't that way.
It was a relatively minor amount, a few thousand dollars a year.
But during our 12-year program, we had received between, I'd say, between $5 and $6 million from Rockefeller in aid for the program.
And that, from commercial sources, was only a few thousand.
Just nothing, yeah.
Okay.
Well, I'd like to talk now about the relationship that you had with the state of Texas.
I'm trying to think of the name of the fellow that was in charge at the time.
He was a veterinarian
and the name of the board.
Well, at any rate, the veterinary group employed by the state of Texas, state veterinarians, do have a keen interest in health of livestock in Texas.
So they're much concerned about any group which is contributing toward improving health of Texas cattle and increasing opportunities for Texas livestock to be exported.
They're also very much concerned about foreign diseases which are a threat to Texas livestock.
And it's the Texas Animal Health Commission that I was trying to think about here.
They were greatly concerned and involved us considerably when Benzoylan equine encephalomyelitis came into southern Texas in 1971 and 72.
And because I'd had experience with that disease in terms of manufacturing vaccine at Walter Reed and some other exposure prior to that, I became very much involved in that
threat to the United States when the disease moved from Mexico into Texas.

And so I met several times at that time with a group of state veterinarians, the Animal Health Commission, and worked closely with them for several months on this equine encephalomyelitis problem that we had here.
Well, what happened?
Well, there was
Quite a few thousand Texas horses lost because of that disease in 71 and 72.
But fortunately, the vaccine we had developed in the late 40s and 50s at Walter Reed was subsequently produced by some manufacturing biologic houses in the United States, which made it available for
for the vaccination of Texas horses and for those in many states across the southern half of the United States.
So those vaccines that had been developed years before were effective in stopping the outbreak in the United States and kept it from sweeping the country.
So that work we had done earlier was what really saved the horse industry in this country.
Now let's switch to the relations that you had with the administration at A&M.
Can you sort of trace that from when you came here at Dean Price?
Yes.
Dean Price was interested in the potential of a program in tropical veterinary medicine, and so he worked well with us in helping get things planned and organized.

And then he and I met with President Rutter, who was also sold upon the potential of improved disease control, which would not only have worldwide benefits in terms of food supply, but also increase the market for Texas agriculture and Texas livestock.
And so we were then, with Rutter's blessings, free to go out and seek funds and develop the program, which we did.
We worked along very well that way for a 10-year, 11-year period.
After that, there were changes in the administration so that the Tagus Agricultural Experiment Station became involved.
Why did they become involved?
I don't really know why they became involved, but they did.
And when Dr. Trevino took over and when I left in 76, he was not permitted to
go out and seek funds on his own, which were available.

That's at the time when there was some ten million dollars available from Nigeria and substantial funds available from Latin America to foster the program and to improve opportunities for export of Texas cattle as well as improve the health of animals in the regions that wanted to provide support.
And the administration would not permit acceptance of the programs or the acceptance of the funds.
Why not?
I don't know.
I don't really know except that there was apparently some personal conflicts between Trujillo and some higher level administration people.
In the president's office?
No, it was the experiment station.
But you weren't directly under the Experiment Station.
No.
I mean the Institute wasn't under the Experiment Station.
No, it was under the College of Veterinary Medicine.

But it was because of that barrier there that projects were not moved up to the International Programs Office where they would have okayed them and where we could have gotten on with the, the Institute could have gotten on with the programs.
But because of that
impossible hurdle.
The institute practically died on the vine out there, and that's been the trouble.
Well, what happened to Shelton?
I mean, why didn't the dean?
Because the experiment station, to the best of my knowledge, was providing some funds for the vet school that might have been cut off if he hadn't played ball with them.
This is pretty ticklish.
I don't really like to talk about it.
And so now what's the status of the institute?
Well, it's getting minimal support through the vet school.
Very, very little in the way of outside funds.
Who's getting the outside funds then?
There isn't any for this work coming from outside, to my knowledge.
Even though, in other words, some other university, college of medicine might be getting it.
Hell yes.
There's outside funds going to Illinois, to Florida, and Washington State that I know about.
In sizable quantity.
And the U.S. Department of Agriculture is now spending a million and a half dollars a year in Washington State that was originally intended to come here, but not accepted.
No kidding.
It's a damn tragedy.
It really is.

And part of our staff, Dr. Cutler and two other people that were on the staff here are now running the program in Washington State that they would like to be carrying on here and getting excellent USDA support.
So it's unfortunate.
I just don't understand why.
I know I might be belaboring the point, but I just don't understand why we would not accept that type of money that seems so, and especially when we're the first institute in the entire country.
It makes no sense to me whatsoever.
It's a tragedy.
And I think it's purely a personal matter, the one individual that's standing in the way.
And I'm in hopes that
I've had some talks with Vanderveer, not about this specific problem, but about his interest in world food problems.
And he's appointed me to the committee to participate with the large seminar he wants to have held here in 84 on world food problem.
I'm in hopes that he will have a different attitude and can take that barrier out of

pipeline that we've got in now so that this thing can function again because there's tremendous need for what can be done and people here eager to do it there are there about four faculty members out here now that are formerly with the program that would be eager to work in this area they spent time overseas with us and
or know the importance of it and be glad to do research in this area if they were simply permitted to do it in terms of getting funding and so on.
I don't understand exactly why anyone would stand in the way of this.
No, I can't either except that when Dr. Trevino wanted to go out and get the money to do a project, he was told that
That wasn't his job, to go get the money that had to be done by somebody on a higher level.
So he didn't get to go, and so the money never came.
But why didn't you have these problems?
Because President Rutter had simply said, you fellows get on with it, and we did.
Nobody stood in our way.
And we never got 10 cents from the experiment station and never wanted it, because we wanted to be free to do as we chose, you see.
And at that time the vet school wasn't getting hardly anything from the experiment station either.
The vet school was free and we were free to do as we needed to do.
But once the experiment station got domineering over the vet school and after they appointed the current associate dean for research who took my job,
As an assistant to the director of the experiment station, that was the end of everything.
Because he has to do what he's told by the experiment station.
It's a damn tragedy what's happened.
Has the experiment station getting in on funding, has their funding increased to the College of Veterinary Medicine quite a bit?
It has some, but I don't think
It's enough so that the dean doesn't want to lose it, I'm sure.
And on the other hand, has the amount of independence of other parts of the vet school been decreased because of the experiment station?
I really can't answer that.
I don't know.
I don't know.
I haven't really been concerned with this part of it.
I suspect so, but I don't know.
And what do you think the future is for the institute?
Well, it has a tremendous potential if the barrier in the pipeline could be wiped out or eliminated or totally keep out of it.
That's all it would take.
There's plenty of opportunities to get money right today.
In the last year, there have been some opportunities from Latin American countries, from Mexico,
in addition to those earlier offers we got from Nigeria and places like that.
But for some reason, none of them have been accepted.
I don't know why.
It doesn't make sense.
When a program out there would increase opportunities to export Texas livestock and decrease the threat of exotic disease to Texas livestock industry, it just doesn't make sense to me
prevent it happening.
So I don't understand it.
But in your opinion the main problem is just on a personal level then.
That's right.
I think it's one individual who for some reason wanted to dominate the thing to the point that he cut it off and didn't, and for some reason
He and Trevino didn't get along because Trevino wanted to get on with things and the other fellow wanted to do it and didn't find time to do anything.
That's the only thing I can say.
It's a tragedy, really, when the need is so great.
How did you get along with this person?
I never had anything to do with him, fortunately.
I served as the director of the Institute for
from 64 through, I'm sorry, from 74 through 76, when he took my job as associate dean.
See, I retired from associate deanship in 74, but I stayed on for two more years just at the Institute.
Well, fortunately, during that period of time, we still had money coming from aid, so there wasn't a real problem.
And he didn't have anything to do with that, because that was already established.
But once then in 77, he moved from associate dean of research up to director of the experiment station.
And Trevino took my place, and that's when the water was cut off.
Unfortunately, the aid program was due for renewal at that time.
And, but it possibly would have been, plus the additional money that could have come in from other sources, but never were accepted.

So if he wouldn't have become director of the experiment station, I mean, if he would have become director of the experiment station while you were still at the institute, you might have had problems also.
Oh, I think so, yeah.
I think so.
I think anybody would have had problems.
At least that's my impression.
Well, that's a shame.
You would think that the Experiment Station would want to increase funding.
Yeah, I don't understand it.
I don't understand it at all.
But you think that Vandiver might be moving?
I hope so.
I certainly do.
There was a meeting of the Animal Health Commission in which Trevino was present and Experiment Station Director was present.
Gil got up and sold them on the need for acceptance of some foreign funds to get on with the program.
And the other man got up right afterward and said that the Experiment Station wouldn't have anything to do with it.
What was the reasoning?
I don't know.
I don't know.
It just doesn't make sense.
I think it was a personal matter primarily.

I just thank the Lord I wasn't directly involved at that time, but it still burns me up to think that anybody would do that to a program that we had going so well for a 12-year period and then cut the water off just for personal reasons.
Well, let's talk about

One last thing I guess that maybe you have something else that we should talk about, but I'd like you to talk about the development of A&M from the time you were there, how it improved, and I'd like you to compare A&M, that college, to others in the country.
Well, when I came here in 64,
The vet school had a three-year program.
They had condensed the four-year program into three years by avoiding summer vacations.
In order to be able to handle the large number of students that were interested in veterinary medicine, they typically had about seven applications for each space in the vet school at that time.
And there were around
35, 38 students in the vet college per class all during those years with great pressure on them.
And so this, I believe, during that time period was the largest veterinary school in terms of class attendance of any in the United States.
And so there was great pressure on the staff and on the facilities here.
And so during the late 60s,
there was sizable expansion in terms of physical plant at the College of Veterinary Medicine.
And then in the 70s, of course, there in the late 70s, there has been additional expansion there with the new clinical buildings that have just been completed in the last couple of years.
So during this whole period from 64 to date, there has been a steady improvement
with good support from university funding, from the board to increase facilities to better accommodate the students.
And then about, I'm not sure of the date, but around 1975, there was a biological science component offered.
At the time when Dean Price retired and took over biological science and Dean Shelton came in, that segment has grown substantially with I don't know how many students they have.
But I know in the first couple of years, there were 700 or 800 of them altogether.
That doesn't mean any one class, of course, but collectively.

So the pressure for increasing facilities out there to train biological science students, many of whom hope to get into veterinary medicine after two or three years of preliminary sort of pre-veterinary training, that has greatly increased the activity and demands on faculty and increased the size of staff as well as facilities out there.
And to the best of my knowledge, TechCNM has one of the best vet schools in the United States.
And it still continues to be, I think, the largest one.
Now the pressure for student vacancies, student entrances, decreased some in the last four or five years because there have been four or five new schools of veterinary medicine in the United States.
New school in Florida, a new school in Tennessee.
Virginia Tech.
Virginia Tech, that's right.
So at least three new schools.
That's reduced some of the pressure.
So now I think there's only probably two or three applicants per vacancy each fall out there.
But it's still, as far as I'm concerned, doing very well.
doing a good job.
Now, you went to Cornell, huh?
And Cornell, of course, is always usually mentioned as one of the greatest.
Yes.
How would you compare those two institutions?
Well, I think they're both very good in quality.
Cornell never had as large a student body, excepted as large a student body as they have here.
Cornell is
more endowed, less state supported institution in total than Texas A&M.
There were just about 40 students per class, as I recall, when I was there.
But I think they turn out equally competent veterinarians, I believe.
Now let's compare this.
You've had a lot of international experience.
And I've never asked anybody about the quality of the vet schools in other countries.
How would you compare us with other countries?

Well, it depends on the country, but one of the greatest handicaps for vet schools, for example, in India and Pakistan and some of those related countries, is the fact that the hangover of the caste system is so great that
A veterinarian in India and Pakistan will have an assistant that hopefully will do all his physical labor part, and he'll stand and tell him what to do.
And from my point of view, that isn't nearly as effective nor as efficient as if the veterinarian does it himself.
I've seen Indian veterinarians.
stand and tell a technician where to cut and what to do doing an autopsy and things of that sort rather than do it themselves.

Too often I have seen Indian fellows who got PhDs in this country in laboratories back in India that would sit dressed up at the desk in the front office when the technicians back in the lab didn't know what in the hell they were doing.
and they wouldn't take the time or effort to go back and even help them very much.
So I think that's one of the greatest handicaps to medicine in general and certainly to veterinary medicine in those countries that still have this sort of hangover of a caste system.
What about Latin America and South America?
Well, I think it's better there,

for the most part, the veterinarians in my experience, at least in Latin America, have not had the detail of technical training in the sciences that relate to veterinary medicine that we have had in this country.
For example, they don't have, to my knowledge, any colleges of American Veterinary College, like the American College of Veterinary Pathologists, that have to get
five years of specialized training beyond their veterinary degree before they become a pathologist, you see.

And we in this country go through that sort of additional specialized training with usually a PhD involved in order to become a board member in pathology to study the slides and do the pathology with similar specialties in the various fields.
In the United States, most of our faculty are people who have this specialized training in their departments.
While in Latin America, there's a relative minimum of people that have got specialized training, unless they've gotten it abroad.
Now, some have gone abroad and come to the States and to England and so on and got specialized training.
But they're a minimal fraction of their faculty as compared to the United States.
And I think that's true.
And certainly it's true in Africa and in Asian countries.
What about Europe?
In Europe, the quality there is more comparable to that in the United States with specialized training.
And how about Canada?
Yes, I think Canada is very comparable to the United States also.
I worked for several years in Canada at this war disease control station on an island out in the St. Lawrence River.
Oh really?
During the early part of the war.
And worked with Canadian veterinarians and I thought they were very comparable with those in the States.
You might be a little interested in that.
We worked up there on rinderpest primarily because it was considered a major...
